titleInfo.title: PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 1695, REGISTER OF COPYRIGHTS SELECTION AND ACCOUNTABILITY ACT OF 2017

extension.searchTitle: PROVIDING FOR CONSIDERATION OF H.R. 1695, REGISTER OF COPYRIGHTS SELECTION AND ACCOUNTABILITY ACT OF 2017; Congressional Record Vol. 163, No. 71

congVote.result: So the previous question was ordered.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Register of Copyrights Selection and Accountability Act of 2017
Register of Copyrights Selection and Accountability Act of 2017
congVote.dailyDigestSummary: The House passed H.R. 1695, to amend title 17, United States Code, to provide additional responsibilities for the Register of Copyrights, by a yea-and-nay vote of 378 yeas to 48 nays, Roll No. 227.<P/>Pursuant to the Rule, an amendment in the nature of a substitute consisting of the text of Rules Committee Print 115-13 shall be considered as an original bill for the purpose of amendment under the five-minute rule, in lieu of the amendment in the nature of a substitute recommended by the Committee on the Judiciary now printed in the bill.<P/>Judy Chu (CA) amendment (No. 2 printed in H. Rept. 115-95) that specifies that nothing in the bill shall impact the mandatory deposit requirements of title 17; and<P/>Deutch amendment (No. 1 printed in H. Rept. 115-95) that requires the Register of Copyrights to be capable of identifying and supervising a Chief Information Officer or similar official responsible for managing information technology systems (by a recorded vote of 410 ayes to 14 noes, Roll No. 226).<P/>H. Res. 275, the rule providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1695) was agreed to by a recorded vote of 237 ayes to 186 noes, Roll No. 225, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 234 yeas to 191 nays, Roll No. 224.

The House passed H.R. 1695, to amend title 17, United States Code, to provide additional responsibilities for the Register of Copyrights, by a yea-and-nay vote of 378 yeas to 48 nays, Roll No. 227.<P/>Pursuant to the Rule, an amendment in the nature of a substitute consisting of the text of Rules Committee Print 115-13 shall be considered as an original bill for the purpose of amendment under the five-minute rule, in lieu of the amendment in the nature of a substitute recommended by the Committee on the Judiciary now printed in the bill.<P/>Judy Chu (CA) amendment (No. 2 printed in H. Rept. 115-95) that specifies that nothing in the bill shall impact the mandatory deposit requirements of title 17; and<P/>Deutch amendment (No. 1 printed in H. Rept. 115-95) that requires the Register of Copyrights to be capable of identifying and supervising a Chief Information Officer or similar official responsible for managing information technology systems (by a recorded vote of 410 ayes to 14 noes, Roll No. 226).<P/>H. Res. 275, the rule providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1695) was agreed to by a recorded vote of 237 ayes to 186 noes, Roll No. 225, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 234 yeas to 191 nays, Roll No. 224.<P/>Pursuant to section 2 of H. Res. 275, H. Res. 254 was laid on the table.

congVote.result: So the resolution was agreed to.
congVote.dailyDigestCategory1: Register of Copyrights Selection and Accountability Act of 2017
Register of Copyrights Selection and Accountability Act of 2017

Rept. 115-95) that specifies that nothing in the bill shall impact the mandatory deposit requirements of title 17; and<P/>Deutch amendment (No. 1 printed in H. Rept. 115-95) that requires the Register of Copyrights to be capable of identifying and supervising a Chief Information Officer or similar official responsible for managing information technology systems (by a recorded vote of 410 ayes to 14 noes, Roll No. 226).<P/>H. Res. 275, the rule providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1695) was agreed to by a recorded vote of 237 ayes to 186 noes, Roll No. 225, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 234 yeas to 191 nays, Roll No. 224.<P/>Pursuant to section 2 of H. Rept. 115-95) that requires the Register of Copyrights to be capable of identifying and supervising a Chief Information Officer or similar official responsible for managing information technology systems (by a recorded vote of 410 ayes to 14 noes, Roll No. 226).<P/>H. Res. 275, the rule providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 1695) was agreed to by a recorded vote of 237 ayes to 186 noes, Roll No. 225, after the previous question was ordered by a yea-and-nay vote of 234 yeas to 191 nays, Roll No. 224.
